reviewText: it was ok and on time
Average 1930s B-Western....I am a Randolph Scott fan-so I enjoyed it

As westerns go this is a fairly good one. Randolph Scott is the a typical western hero. He saves the day as always. If you're like me and enjoy westerns, where the good guys wore white hats and the bad guys wore black hats. Then this movie is for you. Enjoy it. Almost everyone who played in westerns is in it. Some of my all time favorites appear in this one.
Andy Devine, Brian Donlevy, George Marshall, Henry Hathaway, Broderick Crawford, and last but not least the lovely Kay Francis. United artist really went all out on this one.

As a fan of the western genre, I had no problem with the acting and plot line as they are typical of 1930's era films.  That said, this is probably the worst tape to DVD transfer I've ever seen.  Saturday morning TV presentations weren't this bad.  Stay away from this film in it's current form (Alpha Home Entertainment ALP 5205D distributed by [...]).  It's almost unwatchable.
The DVD picture wasn't very clear. I always like Randolph Scoot movies
Good story and Randolph is always great.
I enjoyed the movie itself, but the dvd copy was terrible, more could have been done to clean this up.
Scrathed disc.  Skipped over as much as it showed.

A very old movie. Randolph Scott was very young but this was a fun watch. Don't expect it to be todays quality since this movie is one of his first. It's clear and the sound was great. It's a must for any true Randolph Scott fan. It's every bit as good as John Wayne's first movies.

WHEN THE WEST WAS YOUNG (1932), originally "Heritage of the Desert," is a Paramount production shot on the company's ranch in Agoura. Originally by Zane Grey, this Utah set story, as delimned by director Henry Hathaway, has the cliché western plot devices: rustling, a land grab, galloping gangs, a showdown, etc. At least Randy Scott is nice to look at. Also with Sally Blane, J. Farrell MacDonald, "Big Boy" Williams and other familiar stock players. As of 5/17 it's rated 5.8 at IMDb. . Another PARAMOUNT adapted Zane Grey novel that's directed by Charles Barton (he later worked extensively with Abbott & Costello), THE FIGHTING WESTERNER (originally "Rocky Mountain Mystery") is a low-budget programmer that effectively combines the western and who-dun-it genres and offers a few casting surprises, namely Ann Sheridan and Randolph Scott at the beginning of their careers. Also appearing is 19th Century stage actress Mrs. Leslie Carter as the family matriarch. THE STORY-- A mining engineer (Scott) investigating the mysterious disappearance of his brother-in-law joins forces with a crusty deputy sheriff (Sale) who is himself looking into the murder of a mine owner. When two more people die, all the suspects have alibis. Also recommended: In 1936, Randy Scott starred as "Hawkeye" in an excellent version of J.F. Cooper's THE LAST OF THE MOHICANS. Parenthetical number preceding title is a 1 to 10 IMDb viewer poll rating. (6.0) Rocky Mountain Mystery (1935) - Charles 'Chic' Sale, Mrs. Leslie Carter, Kathleen Burke, Ann Sheridan, George F. Marion, James Eagles, Howard Wilson, Willie Fung, Florence Roberts/Randolph Scott
Scott and good movies go together I recommend his movies all of them
